title: 113_hr2168
content: The "Helping Heroes Vote Act of 2013" requires the provision of information to election officials on deployments of absent uniformed services voters. The "Helping Heroes Vote Act of 2013" mandates the Secretary of Defense to notify state election officials of any address changes for absent uniformed services voters deployed for more than 30 days. The amendment applies to deployments or redeployments after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. REVISIONS TO 45-DAY ABSENTEE BALLOT TRANSMISSION RULE. Repeal of waiver authority and requiring use of express delivery for absentee ballots transmission within deadlines. The State must transmit requested absentee ballots to absent uniformed services or overseas voters at least 45 days before the election, using express delivery or electronic transmission if requested. If transmitted fewer than 40 days before the election, special rules apply. The State must enable absentee ballots to be returned by express delivery if transmitted fewer than 40 days before the election. Clarification is provided for the treatment of weekends in the timeline for ballot return. The amendments made by this section apply to elections occurring on or after January 1, 2014. Establishment of alternative procedures for accepting and processing absentee ballots of military voters and overseas citizens in the event of major disasters. State election officials must establish procedures to ensure the effective and timely acceptance and processing of absentee ballots from absent uniformed services voters and overseas voters in the event of a major disaster. This amendment applies to elections for Federal office held on or after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5 amends the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act to prohibit refusal of voter registration and absentee ballot applications from overseas voters based on early submission. SEC. 6 provides additional funding for carrying out UOCAVA. SEC. 6 authorizes $25,000,000 in additional funding for the Presidential designee under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, which will remain available until expended.
